H0.text: Deposition at transform boundaries has added material to the western coast of the United States, causing it to increase in size over millions of years.

H1.text: Accretion at convergent boundaries has added material to the western coast of the United States, contributing to its size increase over millions of years.

H2.text: Landslides at divergent boundaries are the process that has added material to the western coast of the United States over millions of years.

H3.text: The meteorite impact at convergent boundaries has added material to the western coast of the United States, contributing to its size increase over millions of years.

A4.text: Accretion involves the addition of material to a tectonic plate via subduction, the process by which one plate is forced under the other when two plates collide.

A5.text: In addition to accumulated ocean sediments, volcanic island arcs or seamounts present on the subducting plate may be amalgamated onto existing continental crust on the upper plate, increasing the continental landmass.
